contentrichtext.text: In the [[Sioux]] way of life, '''Wakan Tanka''' ([[Lakota language#Orthography|Standard Lakota Orthography]]: ''Wakȟáŋ Tȟáŋka'') is the term for "the sacred" or "the divine". This is usually translated as "[[Great Spirit|The Great Spirit]]". However, according to [[Russell Means]], its meaning is closer to "Great Mystery" as Lakota spirituality is not [[henotheistic]].<ref name="isbn 0-8263-1868-1">{{cite book |title= Before the great spirit: the many faces of Sioux spirituality |last= Rice |first= Julian |year= 1998 |publisher= University of New Mexico Press |isbn= 0-8263-1868-1}}</ref> Before their attempted conversion to Christianity, the Sioux used ''Wakȟáŋ Tȟáŋka'' to refer to an organization of sacred entities whose ways were mysterious: thus, "The Great Mystery". It is typically understood as the power or the sacredness that resides in everything, similar to many [[Animism|animistic]] and [[Pantheism|pantheistic]] beliefs. This term describes every creature and object as ''wakȟáŋ'' ("holy") or having aspects that are ''wakȟáŋ''.<ref name="isbn 0-8263-1868-1" /> Wakan Tanka was supposed to have placed the stones and minerals in the ground. They were also supposed to change the seasons and weather, and plants were supposed to have come out of the ground by their hand.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} ==Cognate terms in other Siouan languages== Wakan Tanka or '''Wakan''' is also known as '''Wakanda''' in the [[Omaha-Ponca]], Ioway-Otoe-Missouri, Kansa and Osage languages; and '''Wakatakeh''' in Quapaw. In addition, there is [[Winnebago language|Ho-Chunk]] '''Mahanah''', [[Mandan language|Mandan]] '''Omahank''', and [[Tutelo language|Tutelo]] '''Mahomny'''. ==See also== * [[Mysterium Magnum]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Sioux mythology]] [[Category:Gods of the indigenous peoples of North America]] {{NorthAm-myth-stub}}
